UserProfile.title: UserProfile
UserProfile.description: Represents a user profile within the ExplainMate AI Tutor application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user profile.

board.description: The user's educational board (e.g., CBSE, ICSE).

weakSubjects.description: An array of subjects the user finds difficult.

isPro.description: Indicates if the user has a pro subscription.

proExpiresAt.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp when the user's Pro subscription expires.

dailyUsage.description: The number of times a free user has used a feature on the current day.

dailyQuizUsage.description: The number of times a free user has taken a quiz on the current day.

lastUsageDate.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp of the last usage.

termsAcceptedAt.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp when the user accepted the terms and conditions.

termsVersion.description: The version number of the terms and conditions the user accepted.

lastSignInAt.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp of the user's last sign-in.

proDailyRequests.description: A daily counter for Pro user requests, used for fair usage monitoring.

proRequestTimestamps.description: An array of ISO 8601 timestamps for recent Pro user requests, to monitor for burst activity.

isBlocked.description: A flag to manually block a user account in cases of clear abuse.

weeklyTimeSpent.description: Total seconds spent in the app for the current 7-day period.

timeSpentLastReset.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp when the weekly time spent was last reset.

firestore.reasoning: Based on the application requirements, specifically the need to determine if a user has a pro version and the desire to store chat history locally, the primary focus of the Firestore structure is to manage user profiles and their pro status. Since chat history is local-only, it does not need to be stored on the database. The key is to securely store the user's `isPro` status. We avoid hierarchical authorization dependencies, so no `get()` calls are needed in security rules. The structure also supports QAPs (Rules are not Filters) by segregating the user profiles into a collection where access is based on user ID. Authorization independence is achieved by ensuring all authorization information (specifically, `isPro` and `proExpiresAt`) is directly accessible within the user's profile document.
